bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 27, 1936

div1.p: Truby provides his recollections of the yellow fever experiments, including Lazear's infection, Carroll's and Agramonte's claims, Dean's infection, Kean's leadership, and the memorial plaque for Lazear at Las Animas Hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 27, 1936
div1.opener:
A true Copy
AET
3559 Jackson Street,
San Francisco, California,
April 27, 1936.
General J. R. Kean,
2804 N Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Your letter came yesterday and I was delighted to hear from you.
I have been thinking of you for some time and was about to drop you a line
when your letter arrived.

Regarding the matter of Lazear's infection, I am glad to give the
details, which, while meager, are I know to be absolutely correct. First
of all let me tell you again that Agramonte knew little or nothing about
Lazear's activities at that time. Carroll and Lazear were each working on
their special jobs independently of each other or anyone else, except
Reed's direction. Agramonte was in Havana all that time with no special
work connected with the Board's activities. When Lazear died I was in
command of the hospital at Camp Columbia (Stark was in the U.S.). I
personally collected Lazear's effects, including the small pocket notebook
containing the few entries regarding the dates, names, etc., of the persons
who had allowed themselves to be bitten by his infected mosquitoes. The
entries were very clear regarding Carroll and X.Y. and some others who did not
develop yellow fever. There were also some entries so indefinite that they
could not be understood by Reed. Some of these may have been about his own
case, but that, as I remember, could not be definitely determined.

You know, Reed was in great haste, for good reasons, to publish
his preliminary report. The notebook contained the only information avail-
able, as Lazear did not confide in anyone, and died without giving us much
information, about his own case or the others. He was, you know, quite sick
for a day or two before anyone knew about it and when he was finally taken
from his quarters to Ames' yellow fever ward, across the R.R. tracks, he was
in no condition to question, and furthermore he would not talk.

Consequently Reed felt that Lazear was protecting his family because
of the possibility that his life insurance might be forfeited if it were
known that he deliberately infected himself. In writing up the first draft
of his preliminary report Reed discussed this and other matters with me and
also with you, I feel sure. Lazear had been making almost daily visits to
Las Animas Hospital and as it was possible that he had been infected there,
Reed finally decided to let it appear that he was accidentally infected while
in the performance of his official duties as a member of the Board; a
possibility of course. On the other hand all of us were convinced that Lazear
had placed the mosquitoes on his arm just as he did on Carroll in accordance
with the agreement of the non-immune members of the Board (all members except
Agramonte) that they would all test the mosquito theory on themselves. I
am sure that Reed was convinced that such was the case. You and I know that
Lazear would be most careful not to be bitten at Las Animas because at that
time he knew the danger, and if he was to be bitten he would want to do it
with his own mosquitoes, to prove the theory.

Of course he did it himself. But why not let the matter rest as it is
and allow the tablet to be erected at Las Animas Hospital? We have all per-
mitted Carroll, and then after his death Agramonte, to make false statements
about the importance of their individual work as members of that Board in an
effort to glorify themselves at Reed's expense. Reed, we know, was the guiding
and directing head. If Reed had not returned to Cuba after Lazear died the
entire thing would have been a mess! Certain failure! It was Reed who solved
the problem with the aid of Lazear's notebook. Carroll was still incompetent
to help him at the time the Preliminary Report was written and Agramonte, in
Havana, was of no help and did not know anything about the Report until it was
finished. I am positive about this. However, I have always agreed with you
that as members of the Board, Carroll and Agramonte should come in for their
share of the glory, and on that account it is best to let matters remain as
they are. But it did hurt my sense of fair play to follow Carroll's claims
after Reed died, and then again to find Agramonte going Carroll one better
after the latter's death. What a pity Reeds died so untimely!

Recently I had a letter from Dr. W. A. Sawyer, who succeeded F. F.
Russell at the Rockefeller Foundation, asking if X.Y. was a bona fide
volunteer for Lazear's experiments. I am sure he was but I doubt if there is
any record of that one way or another. I know that Lazear placed the mosquito
on X.Y. while X.Y. was in his ward at the hospital (not in the Laboratory).
Knowing Lazear I could not conceive of his doing anything to an enlisted man
without his full consent. He picked Dean because he was an intelligent soldier
and because he had been in the wards where he could not be exposed to yellow
fever. If Dean had been tricked he would have complained to me, his immediate
Commanding Officer, or to Reed after he recovered.

A few days ago I saw Sydney Howard's book, “Yellowjack”. So I bought
it and brought it home. (Howard should have sent us copies I think). I was
awfully disappointed in the play because of the many inaccuracies and the
author's poor grasp of the kind of language intelligent medical officers and
even men of the army use. In the main the author's story is based on facts
but he makes an inference, for example that X.Y. was tricked into the experi-
ment by Lazear, which is unwarranted. I wish that he had spent more time with
us to get the picture accurate and that he had given us a chance to criticize
the draft before it was published. Of course the playwright has his own ideas
of what will have public appeal, but in this case the true picture could not,
in my opinion, be improved upon.

Now let me digress a bit while I am on this subject for my heart is
full of it. It was a great opportunity for a youngster like me to be associated
- 2 -
even in a small way with Walter Reed and his thrilling work in Cuba. I
enjoyed it immensely at the time and still feel the thrill his experiments
gave him and all of us who were there to witness the results from day to day.
It is quite remarkable the way I was thrown in Major Reed's company. First
he was a member of the Board in Washington which examined me for entrance to
the Corps. Then we were together frequently when he did his work on Colonel
Black's folly - electrozone in Havana, then at Camp Columbia and finally at
the General Hospital when he died. I saw the operation and was detailed to be
with him the first night after the operation. A most sad experience I can
assure you. At Camp Columbia he had the two rooms next to mine and, of course,
he was a member of our mess. He was particularly nice and seemed to take a
fancy to me, possibly because I showed my admiration for his sterling qualities
and my great respect for his high rank. (I was but a “shavetail” then).

On account of my close association with him at Camp Columbia, I know
what a great source of help and comfort it was to him to have you there as the
Department Surgeon. I know also that if he were living he would give you
great credit for your wonderful cooperation and assistance which made his
success possible. I honor you for the splendid way you have maintained the
dignity of his work in the face of all that has or might have transpired, and
for the grand and efficient way you have really carried on the unfinished ends
which were left by Reed's death. You were doing this even while Carroll and
Agramonte were still living. Evidence enough that you were the logical leader
henceforth. Without you on the job much more “bunk” and much undeserved
legislation would have resulted. General Ireland, too, deserves great praise
for calling on you for the facts whenever these questions came up to him as
Surgeon General.

If I were to write the story, I would show that the Board might well
have been dissolved at the time of Lazear's death and then demonstrate that
all the credit for the solution of Lazear's results and all the credit for
the experiments which followed belonged to Reed. He planned them and carried
them out almost alone. Then I would give you and Leonard Wood more credit
than has been accorded for making Reed's work possible by administrative action
and support. It was you who made the ideal facilities of the hospital at
Camp Columbia available for his work. An enormous factor, I think, in bringing
success to the project, not alone because of what was provided in personnel,
shelter and equipment, but in the fact that those facilities helped Reed to
promptly and efficiently care for all of the experimental cases without any
mortality. (Lazear died before Reed began his final experiments and possibly
because he did not get early treatment - his own fault).

If you do not concur in my suggestion to let Dr. Ramos go ahead and
place a tablet in Las Animas Hospital, suppose you discuss it with a few old
timers, especially General Ireland, and then do whatever you conclude to be
best. I was a great admirer of Lazear's scientific ability and anything that
can be done to further honor his memory will please me.

It has been a pleasure to bring my recollections and views to your
in this way and I think you will find them in accord with your views. If not,
let me hear from you and I will be glad to discuss them with you. I have
loads of time you know.
Mrs. Truby joins me in best wishes for you and Mrs. Kean.
